Introduction

The processes of oogenesis and spermatogenesis are responsible for the production of ova (eggs) and spermatozoa (sperm), respectively.  Mitosis, meiosis, and cellular differentiation are critical to the production of gametes from primordial germ cells.  In both sexes, hormonal stimulation drives maturation through various phases; however, oogenesis and spermatogenesis differ in their timing, output, and efficiency.

Key events in gametogenesis



Early in fetal life, the differentiation of primordial germ cells leads to the formation of either ovaries or testes.  Mitosis (

figure 1
), a process of cellular proliferation that leads to genetically identical daughter cells, produces the diploid stem cells that eventually undergo meiosis to form ova or spermatozoa.



Gametogenesis produces haploid (1n) gametes from diploid (2n) cells via the process of meiosis (

figure 2
), (
figure 3
).  Meiosis has 2 phases:



  • Meiosis I (
    figure 4
    ):  Separates homologous chromosomes, producing haploid daughter cells.  Meiotic recombination (ie, "crossing over" (
    figure 5
    )) occurs in prophase I; this process involves the formation of double-strand breaks in DNA and the exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes, leading to new combinations of genetic information and establishing genetic diversity.
  • Meiosis II (
    figure 6
    ):  Separates sister chromatids.

Oogenesis



Oogenesis is the process by which female gametes (ova) are produced.  It begins during fetal development, at which point it pauses in meiosis I and then continues cyclically from puberty to menopause.  Most of oogenesis occurs in the ovary, but the final step (completion of meiosis II) does not occur until fertilization (which typically occurs in the fallopian tube) (

figure 7
).

Fetal phase



Diploid primordial undifferentiated germ cells migrate from the yolk sac to the gonadal ridge (genital ridge) and differentiate into oogonia.  Oogonia proliferate via mitosis starting at 6 weeks gestation.  Around 15-20 weeks gestation, oogonia enter meiosis I and become primary oocytes (diploid), which arrest in prophase I.  At 20 weeks gestation, primordial follicles begin to form in the ovarian cortex as a ring of primordial granulosa cells surrounds each oocyte.  Early follicular growth continues through fetal life; then some follicles undergo atresia (ie, degradation) and their oocytes undergo apoptosis.  The surviving primary oocytes remain dormant, arrested in prophase I until puberty (

figure 8
).

Puberty to menopause



  • Puberty:  Activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis leads to the secretion of LH and FSH from the pituitary and hormonal variation throughout the menstrual cycle.
  • Folliculogenesis (maturation of ovarian follicles) (
    figure 9
    ):  Groups of primordial follicles periodically undergo recruitment (ie, pulled out of dormancy) to join the pool of growing follicles and undergo maturation through the following phases: primordial follicle â†’ primary follicle â†’ secondary follicle â†’ tertiary follicle (antral follicle).  This process takes approximately 300 days and is accompanied by significant growth of the primary oocytes within the growing follicles.
  • Selection:  With each menstrual cycle, FSH recruits a cohort of tertiary follicles to undergo further development.  These follicles continue to grow under FSH stimulation; a single dominant follicle is selected and continues to develop, and the other follicles become atretic and undergo apoptosis.  Therefore, typically only 1 oocyte has the potential to ovulate and be fertilized each cycle.
  • Ovulation:  In response to rising LH, the primary oocyte resumes meiosis.  Completion of meiosis I causes an unequal division of cytoplasm, forming the first polar body (a small haploid cell with little cytoplasm) and a secondary oocyte (a larger haploid cell with more cytoplasm).  The secondary oocyte begins meiosis II and arrests in metaphase II (
    figure 10
    ).  It is then released from the follicle through ovulation.  The first polar body degenerates.

Fertilization



Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.



Fusion of the cell membranes of the spermatozoon and secondary oocyte triggers the cortical reaction (

figure 11
); this induces changes to the zona pellucida (the extracellular matrix that surrounds the oocyte) and makes it resistant to penetration, preventing fertilization by more than 1 spermatozoon.



Fertilization triggers the secondary oocyte to resume meiosis II (

figure 12
).  As in meiosis I, completion of meiosis II leads to an unequal division of cytoplasm.  This forms a small second polar body (which eventually degenerates) and the larger mature ovum that contains intracellular organelles, mitochondria, and adequate cytoplasm and nutrients for the zygote.  The genetic material of the oocyte and sperm fuse, forming the diploid zygote (
figure 13
).



However, if fertilization does not occur, the secondary oocyte does not resume meiosis II and instead degenerates.

Menopause



As ovarian follicles become depleted due to ovulation and atresia, cycles become intermittently anovulatory and eventually cease at an average age of 51.

Key features of oogenesis



  • Timing:  Oogenesis begins in utero and pauses in prophase I until puberty, when groups of follicles mature cyclically until menopause.  The ovary contains follicles at various stages of development.
  • Hormonal control:  Early maturation of follicles occurs independently of gonadotropins, whereas later development is stimulated by FSH.
  • Maturation sequence:  Undifferentiated primordial germ cell â†’ oogonium â†’ primary oocyte â†’ secondary oocyte â†’ ovum.
  • Oocyte number:  The total oocyte number peaks at approximately 5-7 million around 20 weeks gestation and then declines continuously through the process of atresia.  Female infants are born with all the oocytes they will ever have (approximately 1-2 million primary oocytes, all arrested in prophase I), and only 200,000-500,000 remain at puberty onset.  Approximately 400 oocytes complete maturation over the course of a lifetime.  One primary oocyte gives rise to 1 ovum and 2-3 polar bodies.

Spermatogenesis



Spermatogenesis is the process of development of spermatozoa.  It begins at puberty and occurs continuously throughout life in the seminiferous tubules of the testes.  The seminiferous tubules contain Sertoli cells and germ cells at various stages of spermatogenesis and are surrounded by the interstitial compartment, which contains Leydig cells (

figure 14
).

Fetal phase



Diploid primordial undifferentiated germ cells migrate from the yolk sac to the gonadal ridge.  The SRY gene on the Y chromosome stimulates the development of testes rather than ovaries at 6 weeks gestation (

figure 15
).  The fetal testes begin secreting testosterone at 8 weeks gestation.  Germ cells divide by mitosis, but spermatogenesis does not begin until puberty.

Spermatogenesis



With the onset of puberty, there is a rise in hypothalamic GnRH secretion and secretion of LH and FSH by the anterior pituitary.  LH stimulates Leydig cells to produce testosterone, which promotes spermatogenesis (

figure 16
).  FSH stimulates the Sertoli cells, which support and regulate spermatogenesis (
figure 17
).



Primordial germ cells differentiate into spermatogonia.  These divide by mitosis and produce type A and B cells.  Type A cells replenish the pool of spermatogonia, and type B cells differentiate into primary spermatocytes.

Meiosis



Diploid primary spermatocytes undergo meiosis I, becoming 2 haploid secondary spermatocytes (

figure 18
).  Secondary spermatocytes undergo meiosis II, each becoming 2 haploid spermatids.  Therefore, 4 haploid spermatids are produced for every primary spermatocyte.  These germ cells migrate away from the basement membrane and toward the lumen of the seminiferous tubules as they become more mature.

Spermiogenesis



Spermatids undergo differentiation and transform into spermatozoa (sperm) (

figure 19
).  Key features of differentiation include nuclear condensation (packing of DNA), formation of the acrosome, reduction of cytoplasm, and development of the flagellum.

Spermiation



Spermatozoa are released into the lumen of the seminiferous tubules and lose excess cytoplasm and organelles (

figure 20
).  Spermatozoa are not yet motile and are transported by peristalsis to the epididymis (
figure 21
), where they acquire motility and are stored until ejaculation.



Mature sperm are composed of a head, which contains the nucleus and is covered by the acrosome (aids in fertilization); a midpiece, which contains mitochondria to provide energy for the tail; and a tail, which is a flagellum that provides motility (

figure 22
).



The seminal glands, prostate, and bulbourethral glands contribute other components to the semen to support the spermatozoa.

Fertilization



To fertilize an oocyte, spermatozoa undergo 2 processes (

figure 23
):



  • Capacitation:  Exposure to substances in the female reproductive tract induces increased motility and changes in the plasma membrane of spermatozoa.
  • Acrosome reaction:  Spermatozoon binding to the zona pellucida triggers the acrosome reaction, which allows the sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida to fertilize the oocyte.


Following fertilization, the tail, outer coating, and mitochondria of the sperm degenerate, and its genetic material forms the male pronucleus, which fuses with the pronucleus of the ovum to create a zygote.

Key features of spermatogenesis



  • Timing:  The process from initiation of spermatogenesis to ejaculation takes approximately 90 days.  However, because groups of spermatogonia begin spermatogenesis asynchronously, the testes include cells at various stages of development.
  • Hormonal control:  LH, FSH, and testosterone are all critical to spermatogenesis, which does not begin until activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-testicular axis that occurs at puberty.
  • Maturation sequence:  Undifferentiated primordial germ cell â†’ spermatogonium â†’ primary spermatocyte â†’ secondary spermatocyte â†’ spermatid â†’ spermatozoon.
  • Sperm number:  Approximately 100 million spermatozoa are produced each day and 4 sperm are produced from each primary spermatocyte.  Some 25% of germ cells reach the ejaculate (75% are lost to apoptosis or degeneration), and 50% of germ cells in the ejaculate are malformed; therefore, only about 12% of formed germ cells have the potential to fertilize an oocyte.  Only 1 sperm can fertilize an oocyte (due to the cortical reaction).

Summary



Oogenesis and spermatogenesis are intricate, tightly regulated processes essential for reproduction.  Although both culminate in the production of haploid gametes, their biologic timing, cellular pathways, and efficiencies differ markedly (

).  Meiosis to create stem cells for gametogenesis occurs only during fetal life in females but continuously throughout life for males.  Millions of spermatozoa are produced daily in postpubertal males, whereas only 1 ovum is produced with each menstrual cycle.
